v2KETH-qS-L-XvjCRGSPTg.text: Been numerous occasions, the selection is not vast, the food is simple, but really nice, fantastic value for money & healthy as well, what are you waiting for!!

5JayqhCvI3LYiZvUqIXsoQ.text: Lived in the area for a good three months before moving home to the US, and this was my go-to spot for comfort food. Tucked away, but worth the walk. Very cheap! Not so much selection, but still pretty solid. I returned after 1.5 years during a short weekend visit to London, and the man at the counter recognized me! Probably because I was the American girl who always came here alone, but cool nonetheless. The prices were raised, but still a good deal.

v26et86PIwzCkSdtxSM8gQ.text: i LOVED it. for £3.95 how could I NOT? it really reminded me of a REAL Indian food buffet, like something in India! they even said so themselves "this is a real indian food buffet" (this was sprinkled amongst all the other "information" that they were "informing" me of by plastering "informative" posters and billboards all over the walls) James D. had told me about this lil gem, and I DEMANDED that he take me there. and boy was he glad he did b/c this place was a total keeper. James and I had a foolish goal of "getting our moneys worth" by trying to eat more servings than anyone really should, but un-heroically we only made it to 2 plates. oh well, better luck next time, and there WILL be a next time.

6oTFGfLx7pe_Qi2hSJHJ4g.text: When at uni down the road, this was our number one dinner spot. So cheap at £3.80 for all you can eat and without the worry of cheap meat, you really can't go wrong. It's not a beautiful place and not one where you'd likely linger, but for a quick fill it's ideal. The posters all over the walls encouraging a vegan lifestyle are an excellent talking point, and one I'm actually in agreement with, but I'm not sure the amount of salt that comes on the food is in line with the health benefits this place claims!As for the food itself, it's good but by no means amazing. As the price is low, the amount of vegetables understandably has to be skimped upon in favour of cheaper options like chick peas. There are chutneys, mini popadoms, salads, brown and pilaf rice, and a selection of basic samosas. It's all good and hearty, but a little on the salty side, and something you'd likely be disappointed in if it weren't for the price.But of course the price is why you're there, so if you're after some shockingly good value Indian food then look no further

CKH5R9A33qbL2U0F9HoWPQ.text: It's hard to find good food for under a fiver anywhere, especially in London. But Indian Veg Bhelpoori House does exactly that: all you can eat vegetarian buffet for £3.95 every day from midday till 11.30pm. Just 5 minutes walk from Angel tube, this place is also in my favourite location in London.When I went on a week day lunchtime, there was no waiting, we were simply shown our table by the lone guy running the show and then left to eat our way through as much as we could manage. There was a selection of salads, three types of rice and four or five curries as well as naan breads and various bhajis. All of the curries were relatively mild, or at least there were no eye-watering dishes (which was good for me but others might see that as a down side).  You could also help yourself to drinks from the fridge and then pay for everything on your way out.There are some amusing posters on the walls claiming that the vegetarian diet is how all the Bollywood princesses achieve their beauty. The rest of the wall space is full of vegetarianism promotion, and reasons for leaving your carnivore habits. As a meat eater this didn't put me off it actually made me wonder if what they said was right...The food was really delicious and didn't leave me feeling ill (like so many all-you can-eats often do). It wasn't too busy and the people in there were a real mix, from single individuals to families, from friends and couples to people on lunch meetings. It's not the sort of place to go if you want to be treated by attentive waiters, but if you just want some good, tasty food and are happy to serve your self - this place is excellent.

8VZ4Tyqt1Kd5zlRhn0QNEQ.text: What an interesting find! For 3.95 all you can eat I ate all I could eat. I was stuffed afterwards having tried all the mostly good, mainly greasy, rich curries they had at the buffet. Combine them with a choice of three different types of rice (including brown rice), papadums, fried onions or some of the interesting orange-flavoured cabbage salads (try it yourself, surprisingly, yes, this combination does work!). Food was good, great value, certainly, especially considering the calorie per pound value ;-) I wish it had been less greasy and more varied in taste. Drinks are very cheap and they have some great fruit juices and all sorts of teas on offer. Even though I've had much better Indian food in London, the uniqueness of this truely, utterly (am I going to far calling it militantly?) vegetarian place was well worth the visit. Make sure you sit in a good spot where you can see as many of the posters as possible. Anybody who has read the weird facts poster on the wall - I'm still trying to figure out what the longest word of the English language is. It said it is a part of the DNA and contains more than 1000 letters?

h6h0vON3LEHzuQmPhpq8fA.text: This place is a real find. Indian Veg has an all you can eat buffet of vegetarian Indian food. For £3.50 a head. That is an incredible bargain. And the price does not change depending on the time of day, like many all you can eat buffets. The decor is very much its own. Massive boards with vegetarian propaganda cover every single wall. This is excellent should you be on a date with someone really boring, as there's plenty to read about. The food is very good, and it's unlimited. The feeling is slightly if a community cafe or a canteen, but that adds to the charm. They have a great selection of drinks ranging from 99p to £2.50. I had a mango lassi, which was really lovely. They also have non dairy options.

9AteKSSVls7XMXadfh7glg.text: Well I can't argue with £3.95 for 2 plates of tasty indian food. If i had 2 stomachs I would have had more! Self service drinks from the fridge, it's a no frills, no fuss place perfect for a quick bite before a movie.

8a1D6vOiBJ-FdAVkcs6jTA.text: £3.50 eat as much as you like! Usually a selection of chickpea, potato, and other begetable curries, white, brown and pilau rice, bhajis, salads, etc. A wide choice of healthy and normal drinks (not included in buffet price). But what's best about this delightful restaurant is the decor: veggie propaganda covers the walls! Big pictures of beautiful Bollywood stars prove you can look healthy and gorgeous on a vegetarian dietSocrates, Pythagoras, Gandhi, famous vegetarians from all eras are quoted alongside recent news articles on the benefits of a vegetarian diet. Give peas a chance!One of my favourite places to sit, read and eat of an afternoon.

LXI13TxbpVWvTwx1Taxnbg.text: If you're looking for a place to stuff yourself for 4, this is the place to do it. The quality of the food isn't outstanding, but at this price point, you can't expect too much. I have only one caution: one of the dishes in the salad bar (which I thought looked like cucumbers) is raw, chopped white onions.

scFiebAIbpXsL4aHl5LL8g.text: For £3.95 you will be able to avail yourself of as much veggie curry, fragrant rice, and little fried breads that you can possibly eat. It has to be one of the cheapest dinners in London. As most Yelpers have been saying, this place does only a few different curries and some weird fried noodle things. It isn't made to order; it's a self-serve vegetarian Indian buffet. Stick to the curries and rice and you'll be all right. The bottled beer (Cobra, Tiger, etc.) is not too expensive either. The best part is the vegetarian propaganda signs which try just about every conceivable angle to justify vegetarianism:  They give you some pithy Ralph Waldo Emerson quotes. Or if you're a "hard facts" type of person and all that Transcendental ho-hum bullshit doesn't get you hot, read all about the quantities of resources that go into producing one kilo of beef. Or find out that Famous People (Einstein, among others) once said things that could, when taken out of context, be construed to be vaguely about the merits of vegetarianism. If none of these really have you convinced, look no further for vegetarian inspiration than one of the restaurant's most famous customers, 1994 Miss South Asia, posing happily with the owner. If you're forever unconvinced and just have to land your eyes somewhere, try the "Thoughtful Quotes" sign, which assembles little disparate nuggets of wisdom, from Picasso on art to (ironically?) Goebbels on propaganda and the state.

WqMNaRP5_ISjBViPWbLEXA.text: For those of you who label vegans as a militant and puritanical lot, here, at the quiet end of low-key Chapel Market in Islington, is the definitive proof: four walls of pure leather-eschewing vegan recruitment centre goodness. What you initially presume to be a restaurant serving delicious and ridiculously cheap Indian pilaf, samosas and curries is actually a giant brainwashing device. Whichever way you face while munching down your spicy plateful, you are confronted by propaganda hailing the benefits of going animal-by-product-free. Like the boardroom of some over-eager vegan PR agency, chinese philosophers, celebrity endorsements, newspaper cut-outs and historical quotes remind you of how many minutes you are adding to your life just by sitting there and sipping your cool and soothing lassi. Tempted to refill your plate? The all-you-can-eat offer is no accident. The longer you stay, the more you see the logic...

photos.caption: Photo of Indian Veg Bhelpoori House - London, United Kingdom

G-ToKM12fz6RDbI0CLMcBQ.text: Great indian food for next to nothing. All you can eat vegan buffet for just under £4. My advice, use the cabbagey coleslawey salad to your advantage. This place makes its money on drinks and their Mango Lassi is awesome.

9RpXqg0uP854bLPvFOxJ2Q.text: I first went here about 4 years ago and have returned a few times in the last few years, I can't believe they haven't put the prices up (going by the posts on here). As has been mentioned already the decor is pretty hilarious as it talks about winners of Miss Thailand etc who have eaten here, the food is very tasty and is the best value meal I think I've ever had in London, there is quite a good selection of dishes to choose from too. It's so worth going here even once to see if you like it.

CfKTYUCJ5wFvRXWV6v0SYQ.text: I love this place. It's cheap, it's eat as much as you can for about 3 quid, it's all vegetarian, and the food is so good. I really recommend this to all Indian food fans, as well as vegetarians, health conscious eaters and people on a budget. I think the buffet could do with a bit more variation sometimes, but you get all the Indian take away regulars, including curries, rice, naan breads, and a small salad bar. The walls of the restaurant are completely plastered with information on veggie and vegan diets and pictures of veggie Indian actresses, which is kinda funny. It does look a bit dreary otherwise, but it's a nice casual atmosphere. Go here for yer dinner.

JsVBUdWTu1k9yuD7YzRrqQ.text: For 3.95, the all-you-can-eat vegetarian buffet is definitely worth the trip to Angel.  Good, solid food in a quirky--and somewhat over the top--dining room filled with vegetarian propaganda.  I'll definitely be going back.

rkuGnaB3C60owu1HdwP2VA.text: Cheap and healthy food! the free buffet is great and the drinks are not expensive at all. The place is not very trendy but it's really worth it.

qpMBXUbvA0SmAyjJVQyo9w.text: Nestled on the corner of Chapel Market behind the N1 shopping centre, this restaurant is one of North London's best kept secrets. I could spend hours waffling on about how much i love this place, but I'll spare you that. The basic facts about this place are that it is a set price, all you can eat vegetarian Indian buffet, the set price is a shockingly low Â£3.80 and is available all day, every day. Even the most devout carnivorous i have taken here have rolled out suitable stuffed and satisfied. With salads, breads, at least three varieties of curry jammed packed with veg and pulses and brown rice as well as the usual pilaf on offer you are guaranteed to find something to suit your tastes. The staff are really friendly and diligent - the buffet is never empty or cold as can often happen with restaurants of this kind. This is a great place for vegans, and they can cater for parties of up to 20 this is one place you absolutely must sample at least once. Perfect if you are on a budget, or just a cheap and delicious meal if you're not, what with curry houses having the tendency to be massively overpriced this place is an absolute gem.

DTlqxtbl7uX4JJ75xhMUqg.text: I've been coming here on and off for 20 years. That makes feel really old but also really consistent. The food is good as ever and in the 20 years I've been coming the price has only increased by  ONE POUND! I would go so far as to say that it's cheaper to eat here than it is to eat at home. There's no alcohol on sale, but you're welcome to bring your own.

photos.caption: Photo of Indian Veg Bhelpoori House - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Indian Veg Bhelpoori House - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Indian Veg Bhelpoori House - London, United Kingdom

ynnmBkwdRIYXX-DmgUhdzg.text: Indian Veg is an institution. Sadly it's no longer £2.50 per person as it was when I first went, but for £6 it's still great value for as much tasty curries, salads, rice and breads as you can manage. Big fan of the pitta-style breads and mango coleslaw.You can bring your own alcohol or choose from their huge range of soft drinks. NB it's cash only.

QJe0idBG3lD-TzoBjG9hVg.text: Ok, ok. Recession, yada yada yada, it is now £4.50.Still a steal though, if you really think about it. The propaganda on the walls is hilarious. Definitely what I call highly entertaining dinner conversation. Where else can you see Albert Einstein and Olivia Newton John quoted on the same chart? And did you know that all of the world's problems would be instantly solved if we all just became vegetarian? Oh, also, become vegetarian, and you TOO can look like a 25 year old Bollywood startlette at the age of 40. Truth. The 'data' all over the walls, bombarding you from every open space in the restaurant, borders on hilarity equal to  headlines from The Daily Mail or Fox News. Fried things are not great cold, however. In my opinion, just get a sizable plate of rice, slop on the least greasy looking curry, add some pickle/onion/chutney and go to town. Then go back, even if you're not hungry, because that's what one does at a buffet. Eating out, filling your impoverished student tummy, and all for under a fiver? Why, yes, I WILL be looking forward to another visit. Guess they don't know Hitler was also a vegetarian.

Cw3WA_sKzKWlb-XLTrnjHA.text: you definitely get more than what you pay for... nice and cheap and the food is great... iv been to this place a number of times now and will continue to go... even tho this place is a veggie restaurant it still pleases meat lovers... who knows, maybe it can turn you to a vegetarian... :) anyway i highly recommend to check it out if your looking for good food at a cheap price....

photos.caption: Photo of Indian Veg Bhelpoori House - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Indian Veg Bhelpoori House - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Indian Veg Bhelpoori House - London, United Kingdom

1__66kMq-GjqDJahLb42Fw.text: kind of a unique placelots of vegetarian propagandaon the walls, like even whentaking a piss, you will see vegpropagandaquite tasty all you can eatbuffet style, nice and spicyjust the way i like it

ulvL5j_RbhwY5Ae0y6rJYA.text: Pros:  3.95, omg!Cons:  You get what you pay for.Cons:  afraid food would give me GI distress.Pros:  It didn't?Pros:  food tastes fine, run of the mill indian stuffs.Cons:  food wasn't exactly hot.  Room temperature Poori & Dal not exactly my idea of Indian food paradise.Pros:  OMG, THREE FRIGGIN NINETY FIVE, DAMMIT!!!!!!

1xq8VTI7uCr4ZD77m1d6YQ.text: I saw all the great reviews and went over there with the family. We are vegetarians. First thing for indians.  This is mostly a Gujarati place. hence most of the dishes are sweet. Even vegetable raita! Kids did not like anything but tarka dal. The place was OK, while small. Ni dessert as well. Which means other than the appetier and dal there was noithing that is remotely good for taste. Even dal had too much turmeric flavor. Very disappointed. made kids  walk a mile for this place.

GJS6xZUdjfE4IkGORWRcPQ.text: It is the credit crunch after all but don't let that stop to dining out. This has to be one of the cheapest places to eat in the area and is loved by every local. I can't rate it higher than 3 stars though as it has the Marmite affect, you either love it or you hate it. The basics are simple, you pay a couple of quid to sit and eat you body weight in veggie curry. Expect lentils, sloppy dishes and self service. It's really what I would call the lazy dinner option as it's on my way home from work.It's around £2.50 for the food and about £1 for each drink. The tables are a little squished together and the decorations tacky as hell but that is all part of it's charm. If your not a veggie when you go in you'll definitely consider it by the time you walk out, if not for the tasty food but for the vegetarian propaganda that is slapped on every inch of wall available. It's also a good place to eat on your own as it's fast and you don't end up hanging around all night and feeling that little bit uncomfortable.This little place is also hidden from the tourists so generally you get a lovely mix of locals and their friends. Well done Indian Veg Bhelpoori House! Oh and if you can't remember the name of this place when you are there, just walk down the street and it's a few doors down from The Elbow Rooms.

LjpIZKilfSSRrD1FnrC8Hw.text: Cheap and cheerful, with amazing propaganda all around the walls. This is, without doubt, my favourite place to eat in London because of its cheapness and tastiness. It's by no means pretentious, suits all appetites and has a good range of drinks to choose from. Great stuff!

QUUDNrqaS9fRiBuJDaPcmw.text: Cheap eats and great vegetarian Indian food! Walk in, get a plate, serve yourself, seat yourself, pay on the way out. Easy peasy. BYOB. It's a little bit on the dingy side in terms of the interior and street location so I wouldn't make it a date.

Pl9Lf3T79d1bbKXFAjVbqg.text: Sure it's £3.95 for your fill on all you can eat vegetarian Indian dishes (three hot offerings, a few salads, and some carb-y snacks like popcorn, bombay mix and crispy fried treats) but it doesn't stop there.You should also prepare yourself (your eyes, specifically) for a full preachy dose of vegetarian living. It was intense. It was like paying to go to the church of no-meat. .... but it was £3.95.See my dilemma here?

hqFgV6F1xWEd8ywhF7L7Ew.text: The first time I came here I was a bit suspicious.  £4 all you can eat curry?  How good can that be?Well, actually, pretty good.  Nothing fancy but for that amount of money the food is satisfying and way better than any fast food.The curry is all vegan (which probably keeps the prices down) and you only have a few selections (which often seem like variations of the exact same ingredients and curry).  Be quick because the bread goes fast.There are posters all over the walls talking about the vegan lifestyle.  They resemble cheesy 70's era posters from your doctor's office or more like your school nurses's office.  You may find them amusing, I sure do.I've taken all sorts of people here and everyone's always left happy.

_q27n-iXz42kZh-3235IRA.text: This place is definitely worth the £3.95. Sure, the food has been sitting their heated pans and it doesn't look that great, it's still tasty and it's still all you can eat. I would definitely just stick to the curry and rice, though. All of the fried food were very stale and some of the salads were rather unappetizing.

GUKBrLKExjIYi1LlpqidYQ.text: One of the best places to go in London, especially when money gets a little tight towards the end of the month. The food is not adventurous and it might not be the best curry you have ever had but it is tasty and wholesome and at £5.50 it is still excellent value for money. No alcohol is served but you are welcome to bring your own at no extra charge. The vegan propaganda on the walls is a little overbearing but after your 3rd or 4th visit you don't even notice it anymore.

qIwTixoXyI3DASnK2Co41w.text: The food was sub-par at best, and I'm speaking from a generally trustworthy position of authority, being somewhat of a vegan curry aficionado.  Even if I do say so myself.The three curries available looked and tasted like the same thing; they were just varying degrees of greasy.  The crispy items like 'onion bhajis', what I can only assume was vegetable pakora (or maybe it was supposed to be a samosa?) and miscellaneous crispy bits (potato snacks, bombay mix, et cetera) were soggy.  The mini naans were more like pitta.  The rice was sticky and dry.but...well,  with all-you-can-eat for £3.95, I can't argue.

lVdCNtvU5kJkxfuzllXGYg.text: I am rating this so highly due to my strong, nostalgic, muddy, stringy, swelling, unrootable, roots with this place. Yes the curries all taste the same, yes you come out smelling like you were working in their kitchen, yes I love commas.Put all this aside. You are paying 3.95 (used to be 2.95, those were the days). You are eating organic ingredients. You can eat the place into bankrupcy (please don't). I can only ever have one plate. Most importantly, in my opinion, it tastes great.I highly recommend adding a portion of their orange, lemon salad. It adds a light, refreshing, citrussy bite to what could be quite a stodgy meal.  If my 5* rating doesn't lure you in then maybe the all powerful celebrity of Miss Philippines uk  will. They have dinner here after the pageant. There are photos to prove it. You can even sit at the table Miss Myleene Klass sat at. Excellent, if your into that sort of thing.

taeYQAtiKsbf8ukQION4YA.text: Ive been meaning to visit here for like 15 years. Charming establishment with a wealth of information plastered over the walls in what makes fo a unique meal. the food was very good and everything is regularly topped up. They also have BYOB.

LJ6sVpJM8tIV7d1_TXsAyg.text: I have been eating here once a week for years, it is one of London's hidden gems.The menu hasn't changed much over the years, but at £3.95 for all you can eat, I find it hard to cook a meal at home for that sort of price!The place is always busy (but never so packed you can't get a table) and there seems to be a solid regular customer base.The menu us all vegetarian, but all my meat eating friends say they don't miss the meat when eating here.It is a great place to come for a quick fill up as you can walk in and immediately start tucking into the buffet, and I go there on my own often and can find myself occupied with reading all the obscure (but interesting) facts that adorn the walls.An absolute bargain with great food and a lively atmosphere, this is a must for any self respecting Londoner!

WMK-a7C2FZM8cf2Wg4oN7A.text: £5.50 for all you can eat, delicious, vegetarian Indian food - what more you could want! And it's not just good for the price, the food is actually delicious. And the wall decoration is brilliantly eclectic. It IS a stop by for a cheap eat NOT a 'restaurant' for a date etc.

c3k83d-xTrGuuqEyxO3UOQ.text: This has got to be my favourite Indian restaurant in London!  For the price (all you can eat for £4.50), taste, friendliness of the owner, and overall kitsch, it's always worth it.  Oh--and you can BYOB for no extra charge!My recommendation: Try the Indian ice cream--it's light and refreshing, perfect after a spicy meal, and you get all three flavours for just £2.50!

uNB_ERj8V4RUdon34z0G9g.text: We went here on a whim, because it was close to our hotel, but discovered a unique and quirky little eating house. The clientele was all ages and socially diverse as well. Food was cooked homestyle and was a decent variety of vegetables, dal, several salads and four kinds of rice. The bread option was only pooris, but they are everyone's favorite! At 7.95 for all you can eat, it excellent valued. They do sell desserts separately and the dessert menu is quite varied. They're reasonably priced as well. We filled up on the food, so did not get dessert. Next time, maybe I'll try a pistachio Kulfi!

photos.caption: Photo of Indian Veg Bhelpoori House - London, United Kingdom. Just one of the many informative posters!
Photo of Indian Veg Bhelpoori House - London, United Kingdom

Kk3fEwpu21TSAk6XTygAPg.text: I popped in today for lunch and it was relatively quiet. I loaded up my plate with the sides (various veggies such as red cabbage) and the mains such as dal, etc and various sauces. There is also brown rice and pilau. I was pleased by the options available (and there are assorted drinks and desserts as well if you fancy) as well as the obvious cheap price -£7.95 for all you can eat. The food's flavour wasn't overly spicy, just a perfect punch that made everything tasty. The sides are pretty bland so focus on the mains. The decor is nothing fancy; rather there are posters everywhere advocating vegetarianism which I loved. And blaming carnivores for warfare :)I am drinking a star because the owner/person at the till was pretty grouchy. I asked him what some of the sides were as there were no identification on them and that request seemed to annoy him. He also just grumbled a thank you when I paid. Seriously, if you don't want my money I'll gladly go elsewhere!

photos.caption: Photo of Indian Veg Bhelpoori House - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Indian Veg Bhelpoori House - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Indian Veg Bhelpoori House - London, United Kingdom

fMDvU54vaGHFKqN0R6S6fg.text: For £10.45 you get an all you can eat Indian veggie buffet that will let you bring your own alcohol. Can't find good deals like this easily in London and this is worth it. Only downsides are the intense pro veggie/vegan posters littered around the establishment and the lack of variety. Most of the dishes are potato heavy ones, but there is one paneer dish. No samosas or other bits but onion pakora and bhaji only. Again, no complainants since the food is really tasty and at a great price, but some different dishes would be appreciated!!! They do also have a variety of drinks and water available to buy and drink on site if ypu didn't BYOB...!

photos.caption: Photo of Indian Veg Bhelpoori House - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Indian Veg Bhelpoori House - London, United Kingdom

NumBRgT5t-yCpUjJdRd9Ww.text: What a solid, local place. Came here with my best friend, who is Indian and vegetarian, for a vegetarian buffet dinner. We were not disappointed. Super cheap for London and good range of dishes (~10 options total). The decor is extremely fascinating and your eyes will not be bored throughout your meal. Free tap water.

R26HDXaiqz7U0ggJ8wOXmQ.text: £7.95 all you can eat Indian vegetarian buffet.  The food is very good and the price reasonable.  It is full of locals at dinner time, evidence of the taste of it's food.  The walls are covered with food and vegetarian related posters.  It is a bit of a hoot, but ignore the preachiness on the walls and enjoy the food.  The owner is a really nice man.  No credit cards..   I found out the hard way when it came time to pay.  He provided me with direction to an ATM and within 10 minutes he was paid.  There was absolutely no concern on his part about the issue.  If you like Indian food, you will really enjoy this restaurant in the Islington area of London.

If-Hb80QEBZ8Js41FMvYAA.text: Indian veg has been a long established restaurant in Angel on Chapel market, opened in 1985 and still successfully running today. Although set up very much like a canteen with its simple green cramped layout, it's will probably be one of the most memorable vegetarian Indian you'll go to serving a large variety of delicious vegan and vegetarian dishes, self service buffet style and costing only £6.50 whilst being surrounded by walls covered with strong ethics posters about animal cruelty, being vegetarian and some with more factual information about food. It's like no other vegetarian Indian restaurant I've been to which gives it that bit of unique charm. It's a very relaxing no fuss place with not even music playing giving a sense of tranquility or for some the silence can be too much to handle.We were pretty much seated straight away and from there it's pretty much help yourself to the homely cooked vegetarian dishes in the buffet area. Staff were quite absent but somehow made me more comfortable reaching for seconds and even thirds. They were very helpful when needed, like pouring out tap water when you ask. The buffet area was divided between starters which included onion bhaji and fried vegetables, Mains consisted of vegetarian and vegan curries such as paneer with peas curry and mixed vegetable curry. Also a wide selection of sides such as aloo peas, mixed dal, bread salad and spicy potato mashed and all can be eaten with brown rice or pilau rice.On the other side were all the raw salads such as carrot and white cabbage and red and white onion salad and the healthy option of fruit as a dessert. To be honest, the dishes changes quite frequently as last time I went they also had poppadoms. Also there is a longer list of desserts but that's on a separate menu where you will have to pay extra. Everything I had (which was pretty much everything) was lovely and homely. All seasoned perfectly, wholesome and flavoursome. You must try the spicy mashed potatoes which were just incredibly fluffy and very well spiced and out the mains I enjoyed the paneer peas the best with the added cheese, giving it that extra creamy touch. Everything was quite mild so suitable for most palates. Like I said before, don't feel bad about asking for tap water even at the low prices. They are more than happy to serve you it if you ask. There is also a huge selection of bottle drinks at the front but even better is a whole menu of homemade drinks with vegan options such as soya mango lassi. Indian Veg is a restaurant I highly recommend for everyone. Even though it's vegetarian I didn't feel like I was missing out. It's so budget friendly as well offering a self service buffet 7 days a week, both lunch and dinner.

n_8MKoJDBcReOw61XqPWVw.text: Great value for money. Very tasty and authentic food. The posters can be a little off putting to look at and is very overwhelming. The lighting is quite dingy and I think the place is due a refurbish. I will definitely revisit but would only recommend this place some.

photos.caption: Photo of Indian Veg Bhelpoori House - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Indian Veg Bhelpoori House - London, United Kingdom

wcOAfimISv3cnsmX_RGybg.text: Great philosophy and solid food for excellent value, though I wouldn't give it more than three stars. Everything was literally Indian veg, per the restaurant name. A reasonable variety and good flavours overall. However, nothing spectacular to blow my mind. It was literally worth the money we paid for. Service was good overall, though we did not have much interaction with the servers, given it was buffet. Ambience was cozy and local -- a very Indian kind of atmosphere. Walls were covered with vegetarian propagandistic posters. One of my friends said this place has remained exactly the same since he first visitors twenty five years ago. Gives you a sense of the the philosophy of the place.

jXTW1OIacJks5xV1FXFRNg.text: I enjoy quite a lot of Indian food and this was a disappointment. Food was either very bland, or too salty, or way too greasy. Bhaji and poori were rather stale.

mQA36xZGsPiJkPKvoInuWA.text: I like to drop in here for lunch from time to time. It's a £6.50 Indian veg buffet. The dishes are always the same. It won't wow you foodwise but it's reliable and tasty enough. They have some finely chopped salads, a variety of curries (although a lot based on peas and potatoes) and some crispy onion rings and mini bhajis to put on top.Walls are plastered with vegetarian propaganda and the virtues of a vegetarian diet.They have a variety of fruit juices (cans and bottles) and also fruit lassis to order.Don't come here if you want an overpriced concept eatery with a scene and hip design and like to queue up round the block for the privilege. You won't like it.Do come here if you like down to earth quirky places that are unique, good value and want to eat straight away.

wvfZfJ23p1Tuuvb-HcZDUw.text: A small and atmospheric (in its own special way) place which provides truly great food for a very reasonable amount of money. It's a buffet so you can eat as much as you want from those amazing vegetarian dishes, including a salad bar with several salad choices (I love the onion salad which is basically pure onion with spices - super healthy but don't eat it if you're on a date!). You can get a wide variety of drinks, including lassi, both with cow and soya milk. They are reasonably priced but sadly not bottomless haha. The only reason I give 4* rather than 5 is because the general atmosphere is very modest and may not appeal to some people. There are a lot of posters on the walls advocating vegetarian eating against anything else, sometimes quite aggressively, and that could appear just slightly annoying. For me personally it's not a problem at all but I thought it's worth reflecting in my review. Also staff can seem a bit cold but if you are a regular they will quickly start recognising you and being quite friendly. In concluding - I'd say it's definitely worth visiting and having a meal at the Indian Veg, especially if you want some yummy vegetarian Indian food. Beautiful meal for a beautiful price!

eGPFpSiLWTsRQ4YOSRO2Bw.text: Who on earth is giving this place stars? Seriously, I think we should all meet up and have a discussion. I've been here 3 times, and only because each time I've tried so hard to forget it, I did! "Vegetarians Paradise", only if you are a veggie into S&M.I've lived in India, and I've visited here with Indians, and I've visited here with vegetarians. And none of us would rate the food highly. It suffers from the same problems that can plague low-cost 'Indian/Bangladeshi' curry/poori houses: the food is just bad.How can a culture that can serve me the most amazing veg food, enough to make me abandon meat, often at the side of a road from a cart, be so miserable in a large kitchen restaurant? Stodgy, lacking favour, chapati/roti not fresh (often stale in the banquet, where everthing just is luke-warm). Oh I could go on... Please, let me do you a favour and save you from here. If, like me, you crave good Indian food then just walk to Millman Street across from the Brunswick and visit Salaam Namaste. If you need good veg food, then go elsewhere.(You got a star because we'd a great laugh once bopping around to Salmaan Khan's song Bhanjara)

1gbZmRk4z2Y5YtQi3c5brg.text: Don't really understand all the good reviews for this place. Came during off hour for a quick lunch, i swear, the place looks like it is closed down from the outside. Anyway, the place can seat quite some people. there were 3 types of rice and 4 types of curries.. tbh they all tasted blend and tasted about the same- and yellowish with tons of potato. the only more tastable one was the coconut based curry with paneer cheese, and potato. just a note, all of their dishes are heavy on potato. it was like eating a potato feast with the occasional appearance of some chick peas and cabbages. remember. potatoes.then there's the bhaja -fried onion dish and another fried dish, pompadom and some domed shaped crisp bread. all quite oily. heart disease here I come! 3 types of cabbage salad, and 2 onion salad. comes with 2 watered down salad sauces. oh, and some unhealthy crispy rice topping thingies. and yep, that's all. sure 4.95 all you can eat would def fill you up with the help of a stomach full of potatoes. but I'm just not sure about the quality and variety, and feels like I can get better curry from M&S.

kdJrw5u_zf-Fduc9qMRBcQ.text: I've been going to this place since I was a poor little student, with little more than a few pennies to rub together. It was £2.95 back then for all you could. Yes, £2.95! 15 years later, it's soared to a heady £5.95, but c'mon guys, that ain't bad for all you can stuff in your fat face, is it. And it's damn tasty. And it's entirely vegetarian. So all in all, this herbivore is pretty bloody happy. Don't forget to try the salads, especially the yellow fella - it's not all about the curry, you know. And treat yourself to a delicious lassi. And if your date doesn't offer quite the scintillating conversation you'd hoped for, the walls are absolutely plastered with vegetarian propaganda to keep you entertained through your meal. Woohoo, have your £5.95 (cash only, please) at the ready!

photos.caption: Photo of Indian Veg Bhelpoori House - London, United Kingdom. Glorious lighting at Indian Veg Bhelpoori House
Photo of Indian Veg Bhelpoori House - London, United Kingdom. We do, we do! Indian Veg Bhelpoori House

amOV3_TrjBHMJJG8BBYBOA.text: Yeah it's kinda shotty-looking from the outside, but once inside it's kinda warm and fuzzy in a florescent light cafeteria type of way. They have lots of inspiring messages on the walls, which give it sort of a hippy vibe. And besides, it's 5.95 for a buffet (cash only) - which is pretty damn tasty might I add. I am not a vegetarian but I didn't even miss the meat.I feel like there's a joke in there somewhere...Yeah so anyone who has ever tried to spend less than 10 on a meal in London will understand why that's the equivalent of finding a unicorn.

Ase2eFEHv1P4Ydj3c25RHA.text: Sorry reviewers this place now charges £5.50 gasp!!! They also no longer serve alcohol but are cool about you bringing your own (no corkage fee) Whats to say that hasn't already been said in the 2 and 3 star reviews? If you're poor, hungry and cold, head for this place - It's a bargain. Be prepared for the preachy veggie propaganda that plasters the walls, as I pointed out in another review of this place the one FACT they forgot to mention is that the Indian sub-continent has one of the highest levels of diabetes on the planet.

i2EWZdsIaqhkIv-_xY4oIg.text: A real original, in an increasingly pretentious London dining scene. The buffet food selection is second to none of the average Indian restaurants and take aways anywhere in London, freshly cooked bread still warm being my favourite, and the drinks selection is just the best around. Healthy fruit juices from British farms, premium and regular fizzy drinks, freshly prepared vegan mango lassi, and a plump desserts list. The decor won't please if you're hankering after the sterile, hospital waiting room style that seems to be in favour among the crowds these days, it's a cross between a small family run eatery and a diner with walls completely plastered with vegan articles, trivia and dietary facts, on giant posters. I loved the ambiance and the truly diverse crowd, a real local original and a relaxed atmosphere.

CzwqmtJ-jHC_fBD_3RT5Yw.text: This place is fantastic! Of course there were many vegetarian options, but I was most blown away by the number of vegetable options. My plate looked like a rainbow-purple cabbage and beets, shaved orange  carrots with bright red pomegranate seeds, yellow (delicious!!) curried potatoes with cauliflower, green sauce, you get the idea. I enjoyed the curries as well, and ordered a sweet and creamy soy mango lassi. I did not miss the dairy at all! If you're a vegetarian or not, I would absolutely make a trip here. Good value and great food!

QoMeEWV18xm7PeE2cHXZzQ.text: Great value for money. Became vege recently so my girlfriend and I were on the hunt for somewhere good. Luckily we found this place. Insides a bit shabby but don't be put off because the food is great. Looking forward to going back,

g34zfoo8RmTucJVpVxj4MQ.text: At £5.50, this vegetarian buffet is good value. There's a selection of salads, rice, poppadoms and unidentified fried dough things, with three different curries and dahls to choose from. The poppadoms could have been slightly crispier but that's a minor thing. It was all quite tasty and maybe the spiced potato mash was slightly too tasty. There was a lot of potato. The curry is too greasy to have buffet-level amounts of though. It's bring your own drink which cuts down the costs, but there is a wide variety of non-alcoholic drinks available to buy there too. Being honest, it's not the food that would have me coming back here, it's nice enough but there are other attractions...I'm definitely no seal clubber but I am as partial to lumps of nutritious animal tissue as the next man. Indian Veg Bhelpoori House is not my usual scene but I love vegetarian food too. However here animal tissue consumption of any kind is, let's say, frowned upon. THE WALLS SHOUT AT YOU. About lots of things. But mainly about the eating meat. Every surface is covered in incredible, bizarre signage. One particular sign (over the salad bar) extolls the benefits of drinking water. I thought the benefits of drinking water would be fairly standard but apparently it "aids body lubrication". What even is "body lubrication"?  Is body lubrication just excessive sweating? Am I slipping into some kind of figure hugging amniotic sleeping bag? We will never know. I my have misread the sign however under the extraterrestrial blue light of the most amazing light fixture I have ever seen. It is the chandelier belonging in the play dungeon of a mortician-cum-80s-pimp. From the outside you would never know it was a restaurant and you wouldn't really be any the wiser on the inside. I should really be talking about the food but the visual assault on the senses is extraordinary and a main reason I will be returning. It is a relaxing, affordable place to go, if you can find it and if you can deal with the placard-laden interior. This place is Morrissey in the guise of an obscure subcontinental buffet restaurant.
